data.title: Stimson, Charles (1841-1906)
data.meta_description: C. Stimson, Montreal, QC, 1870; McCord Museum, I-45468.1 (cropped); http://collections.musee-mccord.qc.ca/en/collection/artifacts/I-45468.1. Charles Stimson was a commission merchant. He lived at 804 Nicola Street from about 1898 to 1906. Family Background Charles Stimson was born in Compton, Quebec on August 23, 1841. His parents were Arba Stimson (1806–1863) and Mary Greely Smith (1816–1857). Arba Stimson was born…
data.text:
Charles Stimson was a commission merchant. He lived at 804 Nicola Street from about 1898 to 1906.

Family Background

Charles Stimson was born in Compton, Quebec on August 23, 1841. His parents were Arba Stimson (1806–1863) and Mary Greely Smith (1816–1857).

Arba Stimson was born in on July 19, 1806 in Duxbury Township, Vermont. He became a successful farmer and he operated a general store in Compton.

On November 11, 1839, in Hatley, Quebec, Arba Stimson married Mary Greely Smith. She was born about 1816.

In 1851 the Stimson family was living in Compton.

Mary Greely Stimson died in Compton on June 20, 1857.

She was buried in Compton Cemetery in Compton.

In October 1857, an auctioneer sold the stock of the Stimson and Doak store in Compton.

In 1861, Arba Stimson was widowed and living in Compton.

Arba Stimson died on June 12, 1863.

He was buried in Compton Cemetery in Compton.

Charles Stimson: Early Life

In 1861 Charles Stimson was living in Montreal, Quebec.

In 1863 he was residing on Redpath Street in Montreal. He was working as a salesman.

Charles later became a member of the leather merchants firm of Stimson and Richardson.

Charles Richardson was the other member of the firm.

Marriage to Melinda Le Moyne

On August 31, 1871, in Montreal, Charles married Melinda Mary Le Moyne (Melinda was sometimes called “Linda.” The spelling of her surname appeared in various ways, including “Le Moyne,” “Le Moine,” and “Lemoine.”).

Melinda Le Moyne was born in Montreal on November 1, 1850. Her parents were Benjamin Henry Le Moyne (sometimes spelled Benjamin Henri Le Moine) (1811-1875) and Sophia Eliza McPherson (1812-1871).

Benjamin Henry Lemoine and Sophia Eliza Macpherson were married on May 4, 1834. (Some sources say that the marriage was at Crane Island (Isle-aux-Grues), Quebec. Other sources state that Valcartier was the location of the marriage.)

Sophia Le Moyne died in Montreal on April 29, 1871.

Benjamin Lemoine died in Montreal on April 18, 1875.

Further Business in Montreal

By the late 1870s Charles Stimson was in the leather business with Archibald Murray Cassils (1843-1891).

Archibald Cassils was associated with the leather business, both in his own right and through his marriage. In 1873 he married Eva Albertine Shaw. She was the daughter of Brackley Shaw, who was a leather merchant.

Failure of Cassils, Stimson

The Cassils, Stimson business was successful at first, and it had a wide range of suppliers and wholesale and retail customers.

However, in 1884 Cassils, Stimson became insolvent, and this led to the failure of many companies that did business with Cassils, Stimson.

In 1884 the former business location of Cassils, Stimson and Company was available to rent.

In July 1884 an auctioneer sold Cassils, Stimson’s stock of leather goods.

By 1886, Charles Stimson and Archibald Cassils had established new leather merchant businesses under their own names.

Even after Charles Stimson and Archibald Cassils established their own firms, the fallout from the failure of Cassils, Stimson and Company continued for several years. In 1887 the curator of the Cassils, Stimson estate declared a second and final dividend for the creditors.

In 1890 the Eastern Townships Bank obtained a $24,000 judgment against Cassils, Stimson and Company.

Archibald Cassils died on March 6, 1891.

Eva Cassils died in Hollywood, California in 1941.

Charles Stimson was in the Montreal city directory until 1892-1893.

To Vancouver

According to an 1896 article in the Vancouver Daily World, Charles arrived in Vancouver about 1892.

However, Charles Stimson’s name did not appear in Vancouver newspapers and directories until 1895.

He was a commission merchant, living in the first Hotel Vancouver.

The Hotel Vancouver originally had only a central section, but in 1892 and 1893 a new extension appeared at the south end of the original building. The builder of the extension was Augustus Eddy Barrett (1842-1907), who lived in Washington State.

Addresses in Vancouver

The Stimson family lived at the following addresses in Vancouver. (The spelling of the family surname in the Vancouver directories was inconsistent: 1895, Stemson; 1896, Stimson; 1897, Steinson; 1898, Stimson; 1899, Simpson; 1900-1901, Stimson.)

Vancouver directory listings for Stimson family.

Social Life, Travel, and Business

After Charles and Melinda Stimson arrived in Vancouver, they often appeared in the society pages, which sometimes described their travels to various parts of Canada.

In 1902, Charles received $5,000 from the estate of his cousin, Sydney Mason Smith, who was a wealthy capitalist in San Francisco. Sydney Smith died in San Jose, California on January 22, 1902.

Friends with Jean Mollison

Melinda Stimson was friends with Jean Mollison, who managed the C.P.R. Hotel in North Bend, British Columbia. Jean Mollison was the manager of Glencoe Lodge from 1907 to 1932.

Later Life in Vancouver

In the early 1900s, Charles and Melinda continued to travel. In 1902 they went to Banff in the Rocky Mountains.

In 1903 they travelled to Quebec.

In early 1905, Charles Stimson retired from the shipping business. Robert Ward and Company (owned by Richard Vance Winch) took over Charles Stimson’s lease of the C.P.R. wharf at the foot of Abbott Street.

In the summer of 1905 Charles and Melinda travelled to Lake Louise in the Rocky Mountains.

In August 1905, Charles went salmon fishing on Vancouver Island with Charles McCulloch Beecher and Sir Charles Hibbert Tupper.

Charles Stimson died in Vancouver on May 2, 1906.

According to his probate records, Charles had a relatively modest estate. The total value of all of his property, both in British Columbia and elsewhere, was about $3675. His British Columbia real estate was worth $560, and his personal property was worth $260. Melinda Stimson was the sole beneficiary.

Melinda Stimson: Later Life

After Charles died, Melinda continued to travel and to take part in Vancouver society events.

In May 1906 she went to Montreal.

In August 1907 she became ill and she spent several days in St. Paul’s Hospital in Vancouver.

Melinda appeared in the 1908 Vancouver society directory.

Melinda died in Vancouver on December 2, 1909.

Frederick Smith Stimson

Charles Stimson’s younger brother, Frederick Smith Stimson (1842-1912), was a farmer in Quebec and a rancher in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, west of Calgary.

He was born in Compton, Quebec on November 27, 1842. On June 27, 1866, he married his first cousin, Mary Greely Smith. He died in Montreal, Quebec on January 15, 1912.

John McPherson Le Moyne

John McPherson Le Moyne was Melinda Stimson’s brother. He was born in Montreal, Quebec on June 7, 1848, and he became a farmer in Compton, Quebec.

On June 7, 1881, in Compton, Quebec, he married Caroline Edith Boyle (sometimes referred to as “Catherine”).

Caroline Boyle was born on Grindstone Island, Magdalen Islands, Quebec on February 13, 1859. Her parents were Rev. Felix Boyle (1829-1908) and Julia Louisa Arnold (1831–1865).

Julia Louisa Boyle died on February 18, 1865.

Felix Boyle died on November 16, 1908.

John and Caroline Le Moyne arrived in Vancouver in 1907, and for most years after that they lived at 804 Nicola Street until the mid-1930s.

John Le Moyne died in Vancouver on March 10, 1933.

Caroline Le Moyne died in Vancouver on August 14, 1943.
